column2: XX.
column3: x x.

column2: A Plea
column3: A Plea

column2: When the newly-married pair came home, the first person who appeared, to offer his congratulations, was Sydney Carton.
column3: When the newly married pair came home, the first person who appeared, to offer his congratulations, was Sydney Carton.

column2: They had not been at home many hours, when he presented himself.
column3: They had not been at home many hours, when he presented himself.

column2: He was not improved in habits, or in looks, or in manner; but there was a certain rugged air of fidelity about him, which was new to the observation of Charles Darnay.
column3: He was not improved in habits, or in looks, or in manner; but there was a certain rugged air of fidelity about him, which was new to the observation of Charles Darnay.

column2: He watched his opportunity of taking Darnay aside into a window, and of speaking to him when no one overheard.
column3: He watched his opportunity of taking Darnay aside into a window, and of speaking to him when no one overheard.

column2: Mr. Darnay, said Carton, "I wish we might be friends."
column3: mr Darnay, said Carton, "I wish we might be friends."

column2: We are already friends, I hope.
column3: We are already friends, I hope.

column2: You are good enough to say so, as a fashion of speech; but, I don't mean any fashion of speech.	You are good enough to say so, as a fashion of speech; but, I don't mean any fashion of speech.
column3: true

column2: Indeed, when I say I wish we might be friends, I scarcely mean quite that, either."
column3: Indeed, when I say I wish we might be friends, I scarcely mean quite that, either."

column2: Charles Darnay--as was natural--asked him, in all good-humour and good-fellowship, what he did mean?
column3: Charles Darnay-as was natural-asked him, in all good humour and good fellowship, what he did mean?

column2: Upon my life, said Carton, smiling, "I find that easier to comprehend in my own mind, than to convey to yours.
column3: Upon my life, said Carton, smiling, "I find that easier to comprehend in my own mind, than to convey to yours.

column2: However, let me try.
column3: However, let me try.

column2: You remember a certain famous occasion when I was more drunk than--than usual?"
column3: You remember a certain famous occasion when I was more drunk than-than usual?"

column2: I remember a certain famous occasion when you forced me to confess that you had been drinking.
column3: I remember a certain famous occasion when you forced me to confess that you had been drinking.

column2: I remember it too.	I remember it too.
column3: false

column2: The curse of those occasions is heavy upon me, for I always remember them.
column3: The curse of those occasions is heavy upon me, for I always remember them.

column2: I hope it may be taken into account one day, when all days are at an end for me!
column3: I hope it may be taken into account one day, when all days are at an end for me!

column2: Don't be alarmed; I am not going to preach."
column3: Don't be alarmed; I am not going to preach."

column2: I am not at all alarmed.	I am not at all alarmed.
column3: true

column2: Earnestness in you, is anything but alarming to me."
column3: Earnestness in you, is anything but alarming to me."

column2: Ah! said Carton, with a careless wave of his hand, as if he waved that away.
column3: Ah! said Carton, with a careless wave of his hand, as if he waved that away.

column2: On the drunken occasion in question (one of a large number, as you know), I was insufferable about liking you, and not liking you.	On the drunken occasion in question (one of a large number, as you know), I was insufferable about liking you, and not liking you.
column3: true

column2: I wish you would forget it."
column3: I wish you would forget it."

column2: I forgot it long ago.
column3: I forgot it long ago.

column2: Fashion of speech again!	Fashion of speech again!
column3: true

column2: But, Mr. Darnay, oblivion is not so easy to me, as you represent it to be to you.
column3: But, mr Darnay, oblivion is not so easy to me, as you represent it to be to you.

column2: I have by no means forgotten it, and a light answer does not help me to forget it."
column3: I have by no means forgotten it, and a light answer does not help me to forget it."

column2: If it was a light answer, returned Darnay, "I beg your forgiveness for it.
column3: If it was a light answer, returned Darnay, "I beg your forgiveness for it.

column2: I had no other object than to turn a slight thing, which, to my surprise, seems to trouble you too much, aside.
column3: I had no other object than to turn a slight thing, which, to my surprise, seems to trouble you too much, aside.

column2: I declare to you, on the faith of a gentleman, that I have long dismissed it from my mind.
column3: I declare to you, on the faith of a gentleman, that I have long dismissed it from my mind.

column2: Good Heaven, what was there to dismiss!
column3: Good Heaven, what was there to dismiss!

column2: Have I had nothing more important to remember, in the great service you rendered me that day?"
column3: Have I had nothing more important to remember, in the great service you rendered me that day?"

column2: As to the great service, said Carton, "I am bound to avow to you, when you speak of it in that way, that it was mere professional claptrap, I don't know that I cared what became of you, when I rendered it.--Mind!
column3: As to the great service, said Carton, "I am bound to avow to you, when you speak of it in that way, that it was mere professional claptrap, I don't know that I cared what became of you, when I rendered it.--Mind!

column2: I say when I rendered it; I am speaking of the past."
column3: I say when I rendered it; I am speaking of the past."

column2: You make light of the obligation, returned Darnay, "but I will not quarrel with _your_ light answer."
column3: You make light of the obligation, returned Darnay, "but I will not quarrel with underscore your underscore light answer."

column2: Genuine truth, Mr. Darnay, trust me!	Genuine truth, mr Darnay, trust me!
column3: true

column2: I have gone aside from my purpose; I was speaking about our being friends.
column3: I have gone aside from my purpose; I was speaking about our being friends.

column2: Now, you know me; you know I am incapable of all the higher and better flights of men.
column3: Now, you know me; you know I am incapable of all the higher and better flights of men.

column2: If you doubt it, ask Stryver, and he'll tell you so."
column3: If you doubt it, ask Stryver, and he'll tell you so."

column2: I prefer to form my own opinion, without the aid of his.
column3: I prefer to form my own opinion, without the aid of his.

column2: Well!	Well!
column3: true

column2: At any rate you know me as a dissolute dog, who has never done any good, and never will."
column3: At any rate you know me as a dissolute dog, who has never done any good, and never will."

column2: I don't know that you 'never will.'
column3: I don't know that you 'never will.'

column2: But I do, and you must take my word for it.	But I do, and you must take my word for it.
column3: true

column2: Well!
column3: Well!

column2: If you could endure to have such a worthless fellow, and a fellow of such indifferent reputation, coming and going at odd times, I should ask that I might be permitted to come and go as a privileged person here; that I might be regarded as an useless (and I would add, if it were not for the resemblance I detected between you and me, an unornamental) piece of furniture, tolerated for its old service, and taken no notice of.
column3: If you could endure to have such a worthless fellow, and a fellow of such indifferent reputation, coming and going at odd times, I should ask that I might be permitted to come and go as a privileged person here; that I might be regarded as an useless (and I would add, if it were not for the resemblance I detected between you and me, an unornamental) piece of furniture, tolerated for its old service, and taken no notice of.

column2: I doubt if I should abuse the permission.
column3: I doubt if I should abuse the permission.

column2: It is a hundred to one if I should avail myself of it four times in a year.
column3: It is a hundred to one if I should avail myself of it four times in a year.

column2: It would satisfy me, I dare say, to know that I had it."
column3: It would satisfy me, I dare say, to know that I had it."

column2: Will you try?
column3: Will you try?

column2: That is another way of saying that I am placed on the footing I have indicated.	That is another way of saying that I am placed on the footing I have indicated.
column3: true

column2: I thank you, Darnay.
column3: I thank you, Darnay.

column2: I may use that freedom with your name?"
column3: I may use that freedom with your name?"

column2: I think so, Carton, by this time.
column3: I think so, Carton, by this time.

column2: They shook hands upon it, and Sydney turned away.
column3: They shook hands upon it, and Sydney turned away.

column2: Within a minute afterwards, he was, to all outward appearance, as unsubstantial as ever.
column3: Within a minute afterwards, he was, to all outward appearance, as unsubstantial as ever.

column2: When he was gone, and in the course of an evening passed with Miss Pross, the Doctor, and Mr. Lorry, Charles Darnay made some mention of this conversation in general terms, and spoke of Sydney Carton as a problem of carelessness and recklessness.
column3: When he was gone, and in the course of an evening passed with Miss Pross, the Doctor, and mr Lorry, Charles Darnay made some mention of this conversation in general terms, and spoke of Sydney Carton as a problem of carelessness and recklessness.

column2: He spoke of him, in short, not bitterly or meaning to bear hard upon him, but as anybody might who saw him as he showed himself.
column3: He spoke of him, in short, not bitterly or meaning to bear hard upon him, but as anybody might who saw him as he showed himself.

column2: He had no idea that this could dwell in the thoughts of his fair young wife; but, when he afterwards joined her in their own rooms, he found her waiting for him with the old pretty lifting of the forehead strongly marked.
column3: He had no idea that this could dwell in the thoughts of his fair young wife; but, when he afterwards joined her in their own rooms, he found her waiting for him with the old pretty lifting of the forehead strongly marked.

column2: We are thoughtful to-night! said Darnay, drawing his arm about her.
column3: We are thoughtful to night! said Darnay, drawing his arm about her.

column2: Yes, dearest Charles, with her hands on his breast, and the inquiring and attentive expression fixed upon him; "we are rather thoughtful to-night, for we have something on our mind to-night."
column3: Yes, dearest Charles, with her hands on his breast, and the inquiring and attentive expression fixed upon him; "we are rather thoughtful to night, for we have something on our mind to night."

column2: What is it, my Lucie?
column3: What is it, my Lucie?

column2: Will you promise not to press one question on me, if I beg you not to ask it?
column3: Will you promise not to press one question on me, if I beg you not to ask it?

column2: Will I promise?	Will I promise?
column3: true

column2: What will I not promise to my Love?"
column3: What will I not promise to my Love?"

column2: What, indeed, with his hand putting aside the golden hair from the cheek, and his other hand against the heart that beat for him!
column3: What, indeed, with his hand putting aside the golden hair from the cheek, and his other hand against the heart that beat for him!

column2: I think, Charles, poor Mr. Carton deserves more consideration and respect than you expressed for him to-night.
column3: I think, Charles, poor mr Carton deserves more consideration and respect than you expressed for him to night.

column2: Indeed, my own?	Indeed, my own?
column3: true

column2: Why so?"
column3: Why so?"

column2: That is what you are not to ask me.	That is what you are not to ask me.
column3: true

column2: But I think--I know--he does."
column3: But I think-I know-he does."

column2: If you know it, it is enough.	If you know it, it is enough.
column3: false

column2: What would you have me do, my Life?"
column3: What would you have me do, my Life?"

column2: I would ask you, dearest, to be very generous with him always, and very lenient on his faults when he is not by.	I would ask you, dearest, to be very generous with him always, and very lenient on his faults when he is not by.
column3: false

column2: I would ask you to believe that he has a heart he very, very seldom reveals, and that there are deep wounds in it.
column3: I would ask you to believe that he has a heart he very, very seldom reveals, and that there are deep wounds in it.

column2: My dear, I have seen it bleeding."
column3: My dear, I have seen it bleeding."

column2: It is a painful reflection to me, said Charles Darnay, quite astounded, "that I should have done him any wrong.
column3: It is a painful reflection to me, said Charles Darnay, quite astounded, "that I should have done him any wrong.

column2: I never thought this of him."
column3: I never thought this of him."

column2: My husband, it is so.	My husband, it is so.
column3: true

column2: I fear he is not to be reclaimed; there is scarcely a hope that anything in his character or fortunes is reparable now.
column3: I fear he is not to be reclaimed; there is scarcely a hope that anything in his character or fortunes is reparable now.

column2: But, I am sure that he is capable of good things, gentle things, even magnanimous things."
column3: But, I am sure that he is capable of good things, gentle things, even magnanimous things."

column2: She looked so beautiful in the purity of her faith in this lost man, that her husband could have looked at her as she was for hours.
column3: She looked so beautiful in the purity of her faith in this lost man, that her husband could have looked at her as she was for hours.

column2: And, O my dearest Love! she urged, clinging nearer to him, laying her head upon his breast, and raising her eyes to his, "remember how strong we are in our happiness, and how weak he is in his misery!"
column3: And, O my dearest Love! she urged, clinging nearer to him, laying her head upon his breast, and raising her eyes to his, "remember how strong we are in our happiness, and how weak he is in his misery!"

column2: The supplication touched him home.
column3: The supplication touched him home.

column2: I will always remember it, dear Heart!	I will always remember it, dear Heart!
column3: true

column2: I will remember it as long as I live."
column3: I will remember it as long as I live."

column2: He bent over the golden head, and put the rosy lips to his, and folded her in his arms.
column3: He bent over the golden head, and put the rosy lips to his, and folded her in his arms.

column2: If one forlorn wanderer then pacing the dark streets, could have heard her innocent disclosure, and could have seen the drops of pity kissed away by her husband from the soft blue eyes so loving of that husband, he might have cried to the night--and the words would not have parted from his lips for the first time--
column3: If one forlorn wanderer then pacing the dark streets, could have heard her innocent disclosure, and could have seen the drops of pity kissed away by her husband from the soft blue eyes so loving of that husband, he might have cried to the night-and the words would not have parted from his lips for the first time-

column2: God bless her for her sweet compassion!
column3: God bless her for her sweet compassion!

column2: XXI. Echoing Footsteps
column3: twenty one. Echoing Footsteps

column2: A wonderful corner for echoes, it has been remarked, that corner where the Doctor lived.
column3: A wonderful corner for echoes, it has been remarked, that corner where the Doctor lived.

column2: Ever busily winding the golden thread which bound her husband, and her father, and herself, and her old directress and companion, in a life of quiet bliss, Lucie sat in the still house in the tranquilly resounding corner, listening to the echoing footsteps of years.
column3: Ever busily winding the golden thread which bound her husband, and her father, and herself, and her old directress and companion, in a life of quiet bliss, Lucie sat in the still house in the tranquilly resounding corner, listening to the echoing footsteps of years.
